p:
Finally, the simulation methods are described. The number of susceptible, exposed, infectious, and recovered individuals at time t are denoted by n S( t), n E( t), n I( t), and n R( t), respectively. Since birth and death of individuals are neglected in our model, the total number of individuals, given by n+1 ≡ n S( t) + n E( t) + n I( t) + n R( t), remains constant with time. At the initial condition, all the individuals are distributed randomly in the lattice sites. They are all susceptible except for a single infectious individual which is randomly chosen. Therefore, we have n S(0) = n, n I(0) = 1, and n E(0) = n R(0) = 0. The initial density of susceptible individuals is denoted by
ρ
0
≡
n
L
2
for an L × L square lattice. At the end of an epidemic outbreak, it follows that n E( t) = n I( t) = 0 and n S( t) + n R( t) = n+1. We define the proportion of the recovered individuals as r( t) ≡ n R( t) /( n+1). Then r ∞ ≡ lim
t→∞
r( t) represents the final size of an epidemic. The final size r ∞ depends on the parameters, ρ 0, τ E, τ I, p, λ, and α. The parameter values are set at ρ 0 = 0.4 ( L = 500, n = 10 5) and p = 1, unless otherwise noted.
